Examination of the video footage: The expert analyzed the video footage circulating on social media that claimed to show a missile striking a building in Beirut. They determined that the video was doctored and manipulated, as it contained a digitally inserted missile that was not present in the original video.
Evaluation of official statements: The expert considered the statements made by U.S. President Donald Trump, who referred to the incident as an "attack." However, they clarified that there was no indication of any kind of attack and that the explosion was not caused by a missile.
Analysis of the explosion: The expert provided information about the cause of the explosion, stating that it was the detonation of 2,750 tons of ammonium nitrate stored at the Port of Beirut. They highlighted that the explosion was not a result of a missile strike but rather due to the ignition of the volatile explosive material.
Expert opinion: The expert, Jeffrey Lewis, a missile expert at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies, offered his professional assessment. He explained that the explosion appeared to be an accident caused by a fire preceding the blast and the detonation of explosives due to the fire. He emphasized that fires can often ignite explosives and cause such catastrophic events.
